title: Marriage ...
author: Ferrier, Susan
snippet: My father and I could therefore only take short drives with Mrs. Scott, while the bard (about one o'clock) mounted his pony, and accompanied by Mr. Terry the comedian, his own son Walter, and our young relative George Kinloch, sallied forth for a long morning's ride in spite of wind and rain.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: in February or March 1758 — may be dated a ver}' remarkable improvement in building and furniture, and even stoneware, in London and every p,art of England.* As John put off the time of onr introduction to his great man, we yielded to a request of our friend Sir David Kinloch to accompany him on a jaunt he wished to make to Portsmouth.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: AVe were a company of fifteen or sixteen, whose names I can't exactly remember, but when I say that there were Sir David Kinloch, James Veitch (EUiock), Sir Robert Keith, then only a captain in the Scotch Dutch, Robertson, Home, &c., I need not say that we were gay and jovial.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: Cardonnel and I went with Smollett to Sir David Kinloch's, and passed the day, when John Home and Logan and I conducted him to Dunbar, where we stayed together all night.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: This galloping sort of preaching pleased the lairds as well as the people, for Sir David Kinloch was much taken with him, and he would have been popular  in all respects had not his conversation and conduct  betrayed his folly.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: In marching down the Bow, a narrow Avinding street, the scene was different, for all the spectators were in tears, and uttering  loud lamentations ; insomuch that Mr Kinloch, a probationer, the son of Mr Kinloch, one of the High Church ministers, wlio was in the second rank just behind Hew Ballantine, said to him in a melancholy tone, " Mr Hew, Mr Hew, does not this remind you of a passage in Livy, when the Gens Fabii marched out of Eome to prevent the Gauls entering the city, and the whole matrons and viro;ins of Eome were wringins; their hands, and loudly lamenting the certain danger to which that generous tribe was going to be exposed 1 " " Hold your tongue," says Ballantine, " otherwise I shall complain to the officer, for you'll discourage the

author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: in February or March 1758 may be dated a very remarkable improvement in building and furniture, and even stoneware, in London and every part of England.* As John put off the time of our introduction to his great man, we yielded to a request of our friend Sir David Kinloch to accompany him on a jaunt he wished to make to Portsmouth.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr Alexander Carlyle ;
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: We were a company of fifteen or sixteen, whose names I can't exactly remember, but when I say that there were Sir David Kinloch, James Veitch (Elliock), Sir Robert Keith, then only a captain in the Scotch Dutch, Robertson, Home, &c., I need not say that we were gay and jovial.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr Alexander Carlyle ;
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: We had Sir David Kinloch likewise, who had come to consult physicians, and Dr Charles Congalton, who was his attendant.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr Alexander Carlyle ;
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: * Sir Archibald Kinloch was brought to trial in 1795 for the murder of his elder brother Sir Francis, whom he shot with a pistol in the family mansion of Gilmerton.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr Alexander Carlyle ;
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: During that time Mrs Kinloch of Gilmerton was brought to bed of her eighth child, and died immediately after.

title: The Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott. (Supplementary volume: containing notes, historical and illustrative, by the author, glossary, etc.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The return of John Balfour of Kinloch, calledBurley, to Scotland, as well as his violent death inthe manner described, is entirely fictitious.

title: The Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott. (Supplementary volume: containing notes, historical and illustrative, by the author, glossary, etc.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: universal suffrage conferred on John Balfour of Kinloch, called Burley, who was Hackston's brother-inlaw.

title: The Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott. (Supplementary volume: containing notes, historical and illustrative, by the author, glossary, etc.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: John Balfour of Kinloch, or Burley, for he is de-signated both ways in the histories and proclama-tions of that melancholy period, was a gentleman ofsome fortune, and of good family, in the county ofFife, and,had been a soldier from his youth upward.
